2022 Narrative: SuccessesIn support of enhancing national and regional capacity for crime response management (CPD output 4.1), the long-awaited Police Records Management Information System (PRMIS) was operationalized to transition police stations from paper-based, inefficient case management to a fully digital, cloud-based platform that systematically manages the hundreds of data points gathered by police officers and allows the data to be aggregated and analysed in real-time. The launch of the platform, which marked the culmination of 5 years of collaborative work, was deployed in police stations in ANB, BRB, GRN, VCT and SKN. Of the 51 combined stations stations across these jurisdictions that have the necessary infrastructure to facilitate the system, 80% have fully onboarded the PRMIS platform and are relying on it for management of crime data. In ANB, 100% of stations had been operationalised by year-end. To support the effective utilisation for the data to make informed crime prevention decisions and to ultimately reduce the number of victims of intentional homicide (SP Outcome 3, Indicator 5), over 1,000 police officers were capacitated to undertake data collection and crime analysis, with more than 50 trained as trainers to support sustainability. This work contributed directly to the UNDP Strategic Plan Signature Solution Indicator 2.3.1.ChallengesÔªøIn some jurisdictions, lack of ICT infrastructure within some police stations prevented the full deployment of the PRMIS system. While an initial assessment of the national capacity to roll-out the platform had been undertaken, it did not fully reflect the status at each individual police station and it was later recognised that some critical elements including internet connectivity remained a challenge and prevented more uptake of the digitalisation programme. As a result, some of the hardware deployed in previous periods was not fully utilised and it was not possible to operationalise PRMIS and in these instances the roll-out was delayed and could not be completed by year-end.

CS2.0 partnered with UWI to deliver a National Crime Symposium: From Research to Action: Focused Approaches to Crime Prevention ‚Äì 25-26 May. With over 190 participants, strong youth participation and presentations on both CS1.0 and CS2.0 including the latest mapping and gap analysis presentations from CS2.0 consultant, the event created a strong partnership opportunity and facilitated a platform for national dialogue on data driven crime policies.  Consultants contracted to provide Mapping and Gap Analyses on youth and TIP, completed their reports during Q2 and this helped focused the projects next steps. Consultants focused on developing youth and TIP multi-year country workplans building on the Mapping and Gap Analyses work, were contracted and began work in Q2 with delivery concluding in Q3. Missions to Grenada and SVG were planned for early Q3 to formalize country workplans.  Consultations with the Media Institute of the Caribbean to support a media assessment on youth and crime and TIP in the project countries, has progressed with contracting due to take place in early Q3 and delivery of assessment and recommendations by end of Q3.  High-level agreement between BB MCO and TT MCO on joint delivery approach of CS2.0 in Trinidad and Tobago has significantly improved relationships and delivery arrangements. Trinidad has made significant progress on the design of the TT country work plan with approval due by BB MOC and USAID in early Q3. It also promoted South-South cooperation between Brazil and Paraguay, resulting in 235 Paraguayan officers participating in training sessions conducted by Brazilian experts. In Paraguay, one of the activities was a Training of Trainers (ToT) in Prison Matters; by December 2023, these instructors had trained an additional 373 prison officers.PRIS-COOP organized several capacity-building and policy-focused activities. In Brazil, the project promoted seven (07) training sessions in partnership with the National Secretariat of Penal Policies (SENAPPEN). The project focused on strengthening state-level capacities in prison intelligence, training prison unit directors at the state and federal levels on dynamic security and enhancing the capacities of instructors of the National School for Criminal Services of SENAPPEN. In Paraguay, UNODC facilitated the organization of three (03) training sessions in partnership with Brazilian government agencies at the federal and state levels. The first course, in April, was on prison procedures and routines for the students at the Higher Technical Penitentiary Institute (ITSP) of Paraguay; then, in October, PRIS-COOP held a Training of Trainers on the theme. The third activity was aimed at prison unit Directors, to bolster leadership skills.  Additionally, PRIS-COOP supported four (04) international workshops to promote prison cooperation and police cooperation to address transnational organized crime within and outside prison settings. In parallel, UNODC worked to support Brazil and Paraguay in the theme of the classification of prisoners. In Paraguay, PRIS-COOP supported the development of general guidelines and an action plan for the development of a national classification system.In Brazil, UNODC was appointed as an official member of the National Technical Working Group to elaborate a National Standard on the Classification of Prisoners of the National Secretariat of Penitentiary Policies. 2023 Narrative: In October 2023, UNODC GMCP delivered a Maritime Domain Awareness (MDA) training course for Operations Room senior level officers from the Jamaican Defence Force (JDF), the Royal Bahamas Defence Force (RBDF) and the Navy of the Dominican Republic (ARD) at the Caribbean Military Academy (CMA) in Kingston, Jamaica. Throughout the course, participants learned about MDA's vital role, the identification of different data and information sources, analysis, and processes in the maritime intelligence context to enable a detection of transnational organized crime at sea. As part of the course GMCP donated IT equipment to increase the capacities of the Caribbean Military Academy at which the course was hosted.
